titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: A lifelong New Yorker, Mr. Carl Otto Kretzschmar von Kienbusch (1884-1976) was a successful businessman who collected armor from about 1914 until his death in 1976 . The Museum’s relationship with the famous collector and connoisseur began in the late 1940s, when R. Sturgis Ingersoll, former president of the Museum, visited Mr. von Kienbusch’s residence on East 74th Street in New York City, which at the time was filled with his burgeoning collection. In 1974, Mr. von Kienbusch approved the loan of 165 pieces to create a display in the Museum. Upon his death in 1977, the entire collection with an important library and archive was bequeathed to the Museum where it was installed, as Mr. von Kienbusch had requested, in a series of handsome galleries funded by the City of Philadelphia and arranged in the style of a traditional European armory.

scopecontent.p: The Kienbusch archive provides documentation of the collection of arms and armor assembled over many decades by Mr. von Kienbusch. The papers also offer biographical information about Carl Otto von Kienbusch and the Kienbusch family. Kienbusch’s correspondence and related materials document his interactions with dealers, collectors, museums, and scholars. This portion of the collection includes an estate appraisal, copies of Kienbusch's will, inventories of the Kienbusch collection, receipts and invoices, articles by others on the Kienbusch Collection, drafts of articles by Kienbusch, and some genealogical files on the Kienbusch family. Correspondents include R. Sturgis Ingersoll, W. O. Oldman, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The collection includes a number of arms and armor auction catalogs collected and annotated by Kienbusch. A number of the volumes have been bound in sets. Catalogues date from 1860-1976. There is also an index to file, arranged by classification and by auction sale, to arms and armor auctions. In 1963, Princeton published The Kretzchmar von Kienbusch Collection of Armor and Arms. This collection includes copies of the published catalog, as well as photographs and annotated typescript drafts of the catalogue. There is a large quantity of photographic material in the collection: glass negatives, lantern slides, film negatives, and small and large format photographic prints. These include images of objects in the Kienbusch collection of arms and armor; objects in various private collections; photographs and negatives from Kienbusch’s European travels (city views, landscapes, castles, people, rooms containing armor collections); and illustrations to accompany lectures. Personal papers of Kienbusch include appointment books, travel diaries, autobiographies, a family history, and photographs. Appointment books document Kienbusch’s daily activities; they include tickets, receipts, and ephemera pasted in. The travel diaries describe collecting trips Kienbusch made to Europe in 1923, 1937, 1952, 1954, and 1959. There are also travel scrapbooks, from 1937, 1952, and 1953, which contain photographs of landscapes, castles, people, and arms and armor. The 1953 scrapbook also includes a typed narrative description of Kienbusch’s journey. There are typescript autobiographies of Kienbusch, which include photographs, as well as a history of the Kienbusch family, also compiled by Kienbusch. Finally, there are a number of loose photographs of Kienbusch taken throughout his life, and photographs of other family members. Other miscellaneous items in the collection include rolled plates illustrating weapons and uniforms from various periods, published by the Company of Military Historians; several miscellaneous posters depicting arms and armor; and a series of mounted photo reproductions, presumably of Kienbusch and his collection. [it seems more likely that these were created by the museum, rather than by Kienbusch -- also possible that they are part of the Herben materials -- not clear from the items themselves]

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
